comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Funnily I think the manmade objects in the foreground take from the view.  It is a beautifully well taken photograph and each on its own would look well but the one does not rhyme with the other IMO!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Oooh, controversial! ;) I actually like the juxtaposition of the tamed versus wild landscape. But what I really like is that the photo wasn't taken from the most obvious spot - directly in the middle of the steps down to the water, but skew-whiff instead...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Have snapped that view myself a few times. It's difficult to capture the (manicured) foreground and (natural) background sympathetically. Though it looks smashing in real life. (On first visit I remember being intrigued when reading in the brochure blurb that those winged horses in the middle-ground are made in - of all things - zinc!)

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: This is paradise. I wonder if they skated on the pond in the winter.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] Photographic evidence to back up that claim?  ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] Yes they did! Here's a reference to someone's diary in 1878 where be mentions skating on Juggy's Pond (it's name before it became Triton Lake).
"In aftn. set off for "Juggy". Found Le Fanu's, Bulwers, Bernards, Pittars, Sandyses, Stepney's, everyone there. Beautiful glaze over the lake after the rain and frost. Had the best day's skating of the season yet."
www.powerscourt.glendalough.anglican.org/pastevents.html - see December 1878

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] Incredible, Michael! This from Rev. Ernest Whelan's diary in the Parish of Powerscourt on Tuesday, 9 December 1878: "Miss Marion Barrington called to see if I would go and skate, but as I had my work I of course refused. Mr G. came in and said I wd. have to go see Mrs -- --- (who was impaled on a gate while drunk last Saturday)."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: Lovely, thank you. And the grand name Triton Lake is a step up from Juggy's Pond!

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
George IV enjoyed a similar view in 1821 (minus the formal gardens, it was just a grassy bank then). He complained that there was a house in the distance that shouldn't be there - it disturbed the view. When one of the local dignitaries told His Majesty that the house was his, George replied, in a way only he could, saying that he didn't care whose house it was, it ought not to be there...! 

On the large version of this picture, you can just about make out the house to the right of the granite ball in the foreground. Today, George would be happy to know, it is almost completely obscured by trees.

comment.author: 53686581@N05
comment._content: I've always wondered: How did those fountains shoot water so high in the air with no electricity?
